subject: Deciphering your pet's emotions...possible?  We'll tell you tonight on the CBS EVENING NEWS WITH KATIE COURIC

(CBS) QUOTE OF 
      THE DAY “I finally figured out the only reason to be alive 
      is to enjoy it.” - Rita Mae Brown 

TODAY’S TRIVIA Cranberries are one of just 3 major fruits 
      native to North America. Blueberries and Concord grapes are the other two. 
      

TONIGHT ON 
      THE CBS EVENING NEWS Here's an early look at what we are working on for the CBS 
      EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric...
Hi everyone, A dramatic moment on Capitol Hill today: the 
      brother of former NFL player and Army Ranger Pat Tillman told legislators 
      that the military’s account of Tillman’s death was “pure fiction.” The 
      Tillman family says they didn’t hear the truth – that friendly fire in 
      Afghanistan killed Pat – for more than a month after his death. David 
      Martin and Jim Axelrod will have reports. It was 
      another bloody day in Iraq – and the deadliest one for U.S. troops in more 
      than a year. A suicide bomber in a truck killed nine paratroopers from the 
      82nd Airborne Division and wounded another 20, Mark Strassmann will 
      report. And on the domestic front, Sharyl Attkisson will have the 
      latest on the Capitol Hill battle over the new Iraq War spending bill. 
      In the race for car sales, Toyota has pulled ahead of General 
      Motors for the first time, outselling the American car powerhouse in the 
      first quarter of this year. But GM isn’t being left in the dust – a slim 
      margin separates the companies’ sales. Anthony Mason will have the 
      details. Virginia’s governor said today he might be able to close 
      the loophole that allowed Seung-Hui Cho to buy the guns he used against 
      Virginia Tech students and professors. Wyatt Andrews will have this 
      and more. In an attempt to pressure Congress to extend the No 
      Child Left Behind law, President Bush is leaving Washington today for a 
      visit to Harlem. The president will tour a charter school that has soaring 
      reading scores – even though most of the students in the neighborhood live 
      at or near the poverty level. Byron Pitts is going along and will 
      bring you the story. Finally, a tale about dogs’ tails. Of course 
      animal body language can tell you a lot, but is deciphering your pet’s 
      emotion as easy as seeing which direction its tail wags? Richard 
      Schlesinger has gone to fetch the story. Thanks! Katie

Here is a look at one of the stories we are working on for 
      Wednesday's broadcast A chilling insurgent ambush caught on tape. 
      We'll show you what's it like to live through an attack using improvised 
      explosive devices or IED's . That story, plus much more, Wednesday night 
      on the CBS Evening News. If you would like more information on the 
      broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
      evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Actor David Hyde Pierce 
      will join Dave tonight along with real estate developer/reality TV 
      star Ivanka Trump… Plus, musical guest Corinne Bailey Rae! 

WEDNESDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor 
      THE EARLY SHOW 
      from New York. Dave Price will bring us the weather from 
      Poughkeepsie, NY. Along with the top news of the day, we will 
      also have the following stories: SANJAYA IS OUT ON 
      IDOL: For seventeen-year-old Sanjaya Malakar, the dream of 
      American Idol 2007 has ended. Despite being one of the most popular 
      contestants in the history of the show, thanks in part to his variety of 
      outrageous hairstyles, America decided it was time for Sanjaya to say bye 
      bye-ah to his bid for the American Idol crown. Wednesday morning, 
      we’ll speak to the ousted contestant to find out what is next for him. 
      PEOPLE’S MOST BEAUTIFUL: People magazine’s 
      annual list of the most beautiful people in the world is sure to cause 
      some dispute. Do you agree with their picks? Wednesday morning, you’ll 
      have to see who of your favorite celebrities made the cut. EARLY 
      SHOW Entertainment 
      Contributor and People magazine Assistant Managing Editor Jess 
      Cagle will join us to reveal their choices. IDENTITY THEFT: 
      PREVENTING CROOKS FROM STEALING YOUR LIFE: Identity theft can happen 
      to anyone and counterfeiting expert Frank Abagnale knows first hand that 
      your identity may be at risk. Author of Catch Me If You Can, 
      Abagnale once lived a life of crime impersonating others and forging 
      checks. Now, he works with the FBI to prevent such crimes from occurring. 
      If you have a social security number and a birth date, you are a potential 
      target for crooks. Abagnale’s latest book, Stealing Your Life, is 
      the ultimate identity theft prevention plan. So how can you prevent 
      identity theft? Abagnale will join us Wednesday morning with tips you 
      can’t afford to miss. JULIANNE MOORE ON NEXT: 
      Julianne Moore is one our favorite actresses. She is versatile, segueing 
      from dramas to comedy to romance with relative ease. Now, she has turned 
      her attention back to action in the new film Next, which costars 
      Nicholas Cage. In Next, Moore plays an FBI agent bent on tapping 
      into the brain of a Las Vegas fanciful magician Cris Johnson, played by 
      Nicholas Cage. Cage’s character has the uncanny ability to see into the 
      future. Wednesday morning, Julianne Moore will join us to talk about her 
      latest film and all of her success. GARDENING: WEDDING 
      BOUQUETS: We continue our Wedding in a Week with the must-have 
      accessory - bridal bouquets. Olivier is the creative genius at L'Olivier 
      Floral Atelier here in New York City, and he will be providing all of the 
      floral arrangements for our spectacular wedding. He will show our bride, 
      Lisa Mayo, some truly spectacular options for the big day. 
      BRADY QUINN AND NFL DRAFT: He was the football headliner 
      for four years at Notre Dame where he's been called that school's most 
      prolific passer ever. And he might be the headliner at the NFL draft 
      coming up on Saturday. Wednesday morning, Brady Quinn will join us. 
      WEDDING IN A WEEK: FLOWERS AND TABLE SETTINGS: As our 
      Wedding in a Week continues, we continue to rely on wedding planner 
      extraordinaire, Colin Cowie, who has a new book called - what else 
      - Extraordinary Weddings. How can you seat your guests in a way 
      that makes sense and stimulates conversation? It’s all about setting the 
      table. Wednesday morning, we will take a look at the possibilities for 
      what the look of the reception is going to be. If you would like 
      more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on 
      the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
